topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Pete encourages founders not to fear sales; Lenny introduces Pete, his book Founding Sales, Modern Sales Pros, and Atrium, and previews the episode’s focus on founder-led selling, hiring the first salesperson, and tactical sales improvement.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Two sponsor segments: Vanta (SOC 2/security compliance automation) and Flatfile (reliable CSV/data onboarding to improve onboarding and retention).

topics.title: Pete and Lenny origin story
topics.summary: They recount how they met via Lenny’s writing and SaaS School, leading to ongoing collaboration and Pete encouraging Lenny to turn posts into a book.

topics.title: Pete’s background and learning sales
topics.summary: Pete explains his non-traditional path (product marketing/PM) to learning sales as a founder at TalentBin, then writing Founding Sales, building Modern Sales Pros, and founding Atrium.

topics.title: Modern sales versus old-school sales
topics.summary: Pete reframes sales as matching supply to demand and emphasizes measurability/analytics (CRMs, digital exhaust) as the shift to “modern sales,” akin to Moneyball and modern product analytics.

topics.title: Why founders must lead early sales
topics.summary: Pete describes founder-led sales as the sequel to Lean Startup: after MVP, founders must close early customers to learn positioning, validate value, and avoid losing the feedback loop by outsourcing too early.

topics.title: When to hire the first salesperson
topics.summary: Heuristics for hiring: achieve a repeatable, statistically meaningful sales motion (e.g., ~15–25% win rate from first meetings) across 50–100 at-bats, then “package” the motion for others and scale gradually (2→4→8…).

topics.title: Iterating the sales motion like software
topics.summary: Pete advises running sales in cohorts, iterating after each batch, and treating collateral/talk tracks as “source code” that gets updated with each objection and learning to improve conversion through stages.

topics.title: Leading indicators: stage conversions and second dates
topics.summary: Because wins are lagging indicators, track leading indicators like second/third meetings and stage-to-stage conversion rates; diagnose issues early (targeting, messaging, discovery) when progression stalls.

topics.title: Do PLG companies still need sales?
topics.summary: Pete argues most B2B companies eventually need sales (timing varies): PLG can drive adoption but enterprise expansion requires humans; warns not to confuse lead gen with the business and cites Dropbox/Slack-style lessons.

topics.title: How to get better at sales: mindset and practice
topics.summary: Sales requires a major mindset shift (high context switching, many new interactions, CRM discipline). Pete recommends practicing “turbo rapport,” asking better questions, and repeatedly rehearsing uncomfortable behaviors.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Merge sponsor segment: Unified API to ship and maintain many third-party integrations faster, reducing engineering burden and accelerating sales cycles.

topics.title: Reframing sales as helping, not persuading
topics.summary: Pete contrasts sleazy stereotypes with modern consultative selling: qualify for fit, use discovery to surface pain, and guide prospects to a better solution—sometimes by not selling when it’s wrong for them.

topics.title: Practical next steps: rapport and ICP focus
topics.summary: Actionable advice: practice starting conversations with strangers to build rapport skills, and tighten your Ideal Customer Profile to avoid wasted cycles and concentrate learning on best-fit prospects.

topics.title: Hiring early sales: avoid VP first, hire pioneers
topics.summary: Pete recommends hiring 2–3 gritty early-stage AEs before a VP of Sales; look for reps from similar motions/price points who can operate without polished enablement, then later hire a leader once reps are succeeding.

topics.title: Evaluating early sales hires and ramp time
topics.summary: Signs it’s not working: poor activity, weak win rates, and lack of progression to next steps—assuming the founder has provided core enablement (deck, discovery questions, demo script). They begin discussing ramp time and the importance of leading indicators.
